The PROCESSING stage is to process the CLUES to generate the research plan. The \texttt{PROCESSING} software is the pipeline of the \texttt{PROCESS} function in the  \texttt{NLP} module. The \texttt{PROCESSING} software is a Python script to process the CLUES of the INPUT and generate a research plan. Also, the \texttt{PROCESSING} software is the pipeline of the \texttt{PROCESSING} function in the  \texttt{NLP} module. In this example, the \texttt{PROCESSING} software is a Python script. The process of the \texttt{PROCESSING} software can be described as follows.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Process the CLUES to generate the research plan.
\item Check the CLUES and the INPUT to generate the research plan.
\item Generate a research plan.
\end{enumerate}

APPLICATION OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS TO IMPROVE THE PERFORMANCE OF AIRCRAFT AND SPACECRAFT
The applications of composite materials in the aerospace industry has increased significantly over the past decade as they provide significant weight savings over other materials, which allows for increased accommodation of payload. There are over 30,000 commercial aircraft using composite materials in their construction. This proposal seeks to solve the problem of GFRP composite aging in aircraft and spacecraft caused by a combination of factors such as moisture and ultraviolet radiation. 5.2.1.1.2. Diagnostic Reasoning System (DRS). 

Figure 1. Diagram of the Diagnostic Reasoning System.

The Diagnostic Reasoning System (DRS) is an algorithm that uses the CLUES and the INPUT to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.
The CLUES are the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones and references.
The INPUT is a research plan statement (i.e., Graduate Research Plan Statement Title, Introduction, Specific Aims, Research Strategy, and References Cited).
The DRS uses research plan statements submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention.
First, determine the CLUES from INPUT.
Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS.

2024-05-06 13:03:50 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:03:51 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - Keywords: asparagine hydroxylation, Legionella pneumophila, Yersinia pestis, bacterial effectors
Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaire’s disease, has only recently become a human pathogen. Its intracellular lifecycle in amoeba, the natural host, has primed the bacteria for invasion into human alveolar macrophages. Co-evolution within amoeba and horizontal gene transfer has helped shape the near 300 effectors produced by Legionella that are injected into the host cell by the Dot/Icm type IVB translocation system1. A majority of these effectors have eukaryotic-like domains such as: F-box, U-box, Sel-1, ankyrin repeats, leucine- rich repeats, and CaaX motifs, which were likely acquired by horizontal gene transfer2. These domains aid in the hijacking of host processes by L. pneumophila in order to promote growth and replication.

\section{Conclusion and Future Work}
This paper presents the CLUES-GRF system which is capable of providing research proposal success predictions. 

CLUES-GRF is able to predict the success of research proposals with an accuracy of $90\%$ using the validation dataset without consideration of the Institution information, which is only $76\%$ in the public dataset. 
The accuracy of CLUES-GRF in the public dataset is $76\%$ for the Winner and $73\%$ for the Honorable Mention. 
The accuracy of CLUES-GRF in the validation dataset is $90\%$ for the Winner and $70\%$ for the Honorable Mention. 
The accuracy of CLUES-GRF in the public dataset with the Institution information is $80\%$ for the Winner and $

\section{Introduction}

\subsection{Background}
\begin{itemize}
\item Mate choice. Sexual selection is a powerful evolutionary force that can lead to the evolution of exaggerated traits10. One of the most studied examples is sexual dimorphism, which is the condition in which males and females of the same species exhibit different phenotypes11.
\item Patterns. There is a possibility that patterns could function as a signal of quality independent of color because some species exhibit dimorphic patterns, which suggests that these may be sexually selected traits2,3. 
\item Zebra finches. Zebra finches are a model for studying mate choice because, in addition to being highly social, their small size and annual breeding cycle make them a tractable system for studying the evolution of ornamentation.
\item Perception. There has been little work done to determine whether female zebra finches are able to perceive variation in dimorphic patterns, and thus, if dimorphic patterns serve

The study of epigenetics in marine invertebrates is a promising avenue for understanding how resilient these species are to environmental stressors. Epigenetics is the study of heritable changes in gene expression and cellular functions that do not involve changes to the original DNA sequence.3 Epigenetic modifications, such as DNA methylation and histone modification, are known to play a role in environmental stress responses. In the context of shell dissolution, the relative importance of OA and pH has been challenging to dissect due to the concomitant changes in other seawater properties, such as carbonate ion concentration (i.e., [CO3(2-)]). I addressed this challenge by investigating the effects of OA and pH on the dissolution of the marine mussel Mytilus trossulus. I showed that OA and pH interact to influence dissolution, with OA having a larger impact at higher pH. This result is consistent with the concept that OA and pH can act independently or synergistically to affect mussel shell dissolution. 2024-05-06 13:05:57 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - Is there any way to add a password protection to a Google Spreadsheet?
I have a Google Spreadsheet that contains a list of students' names and their scores. I want to share the spreadsheet with a few other people but would like to have a password protection so that no one else can get to the scores. I have tried to create a copy of the spreadsheet and then set the permissions to share with only the people who should have access, but this does not work.
As an alternative, I considered creating a new sheet and then copying the data from the original sheet to the new sheet, but the data that is copied over from the original sheet will have the same permissions as the original sheet, so I'm back to square one.
Is there any way to protect the data from being seen by anyone other than the people who should have access to it? Thanks.

\documentclass[12pt]{article}

\begin{document}

\title{Metabolic Network Modeling and its Applications in Cancer and Aging Research}

\author{Cherise Guajardo}

\maketitle

\section{Introduction}
Metabolic networks are biological systems in which many chemical reactions occur in the cells. The human body is an extremely complex network of chemical reactions. Fuel molecules are consumed by cells and released as waste molecules. There are many levels of complexity in the metabolic network. For example, there are many different types of cells in the human body, each with its own metabolic pathways. Many of these pathways are shared among the different types of cells. The most common metabolic pathway is the Krebs cycle, which is found in almost all types of cell. In addition to the Krebs cycle, many other pathways are found in cells as

You surely want to use something like \begin{Verbatim}...\end{Verbatim} Of course, the code is not valid LaTeX, but an editor that supports LaTeX might be able to compile it for you. In the MWE I used minted, but you can use a different package. – quid Jan 15 '13 at 13:23 

     

And you surely want to make your title with \title{...} and \maketitle. – quid Jan 15 '13 at 13:24

The entire document is provided in a single tex file. The document starts with a comment (line 3) that is ignored by the compiler, followed by a few commands (lines 4-11) that are used to set the preamble of the document. The preamble contains the definitions of some macros used in the text.

The rest of the document contains a series of commands that define the text of the document. These commands should be understood as paragraphs. The first paragraph (line 14) contains the title of the document, the author of the document, the date of the document, and the keywords that are present in the document. INPUT: The role of cognitive inhibition in the development of reading difficulties Keywords: Reading, Cognitive inhibition, Intervention, Brain structure, Individual differences Cognitive inhibition is the ability to control attention and suppress inappropriate responses. It is critical to academic success, and in fact, the later in life it is delayed, the more severe the academic consequences. There is evidence that the delay in cognitive inhibitory control, which occurs during the transition from preschool to elementary school, is a significant risk factor for the development of reading difficulties in the future. One theory is that the delay in cognitive inhibition is a consequence of the delay in the development of the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for executive functions such as cognitive inhibition. Understanding the world and improving the human condition through fundamental research in mathematics and statistics. NSF Mission Statement
NSF in Brief
NSF is an independent federal agency that supports fundamental research and education across all fields of science and engineering. In fiscal year (FY) 2021, its budget is $9.2 billion. NSF funds reach all 50 states through grants to nearly 2,000 colleges, universities and other institutions. Each year, NSF receives about 50,000 competitive requests for funding, and makes about 12,000 new funding awards. NSF also awards about $626 million in professional and service contracts yearly.

INPUT: The Cellular Automaton of P. Ackley and G. Hinton and its Application to the Traveling Salesman Problem
Keywords: Cellular Automaton, Traveling Salesman Problem, Genetic Algorithm, Neural Network, Evolutionary Algorithm

Introduction:
The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) is a well-known NP-hard problem in computer science, which is to find the shortest path connecting all the nodes in a given graph. It has been studied for over a century, and still remains hard to solve to this day. In the paper “The Cellular Automaton of P. Ackley and G. Hinton and its Application to the Traveling Salesman Problem”, the TSP is modeled by a cellular automaton with a set of rules governing the state of each cell. A cycle graph is a graph which consists of a single cycle, i.e. a series of vertices connected in a loop. For instance, the cycle graph C (shown in 5 Fig. 1 with one of its independent sets in blue) represents a communication channel with five distinct symbols (herein called a, b, c, d, and e) in which adjacent symbols can be mistaken for each other due to noise in the channel. Introduction The entropy, also known as the Shannon capacity, of a graph is an important quantity in information theory, and can be used to study the zero-error capacity of a noisy communication channel. This channel can be represented as a cycle graph G in which each vertex represents a transmitted symbol and each edge indicates indistinguishability between symbols. A cycle graph is a graph which consists of a single cycle, i.e. a series of vertices connected in a loop. For instance, the cycle graph C (shown in Fig. 1 with one of its independent sets in blue) represents a communication channel with five distinct symbols (herein called a, b, c, d, and e) in which adjacent symbols can be mistaken for each other due to noise in the channel. Background Due to their

The EPA measures air quality using different metrics. I will use the Air Quality Index (AQI) because it is the most widely used. The AQI is a single number for each county that combines all the EPA's measurements into one measure. INPUT: Do not duplicate or use without permission www.rachelcsmith.com The Effects of Anthropogenic Disturbance on Species Communities, Genetic Diversity and Ecosystem Services Key Words: Disturbance Effects, Biodiversity, Ecosystem Services, Ecosystem Management Introduction: Anthropogenic disturbances negatively impact species, genetic and functional diversities of ecosystems, reducing the essential services they provide. While we know that the presence of diverse functional traits in an ecosystem is directly linked to the successful provisioning of essential services1, it is often easier to quantify an ecosystem’s genetic diversity than to determine its functional diversity. Unfortunately, we lack a fundamental understanding of the interrelationships between these forms of diversity and whether or not one can be used as a proxy for another. This gap in our knowledge impedes our ability to make management decisions that maximize future ecosystem services.

They include regulating services (benefits that nature provides to regulate environmental processes), provisioning services (benefits that nature provides in the form of products or services), cultural services (benefits that people receive from nature through recreation, spiritual fulfillment, education, etc.), and supporting services (ecosystem processes such as nutrient cycling and primary production that underpin the other ecosystem services). Rationale: Disturbance is a factor that triggers an ecosystem response. The ecosystem response after disturbance is determined by the level of disturbance and the characteristics of the ecosystem (e.g., natural disturbance regime, species diversity, etc.). Disturbance effects are the ecosystem's response after disturbance. Disturbance effects are also called ecosystem responses.

The levels of disturbance and the characteristics of the ecosystem are important factors in the magnitude of disturbance effects. In this case, DISTURBANCE EFFECTS are the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.

2024-05-06 13:09:49 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Introduction: Arctic ozone depletion events (ODEs) are a growing concern – they are a key component of the Arctic climate system and affect the global climate. ODEs are caused by the release of reactive halogen species (RHXs), such as bromine (Br), chlorine (Cl), and iodine (I), into the Arctic atmosphere. As the RHXs increase, they deplete ozone (O3) from the atmosphere, creating an ozone hole. This research focuses on the role of I in ODEs. I is present in the atmosphere as iodide (I-) and as molecular iodine (I2). When the RHXs from the winter snowpack are exposed to ozone in the spring, I2 is produced. I2 is then oxidized to produce more ozone. The ozone produced is then removed by the RHXs and a second ozone depletion event occurs. The process repeats for several years. However, as the RHXs increase,

I. Introduction: To better understand the impact of global climate change and the effects of increased biogenic and anthropogenic emissions, more research is needed into the unique photochemical processes that take place in the Arctic atmosphere. Although geographically remote, the Arctic has a significant impact on globally important feedbacks to climate change.
II. Problem Statement: To date, few successful in-situ measurements of iodine compounds have been achieved in the Arctic due to the lack of analytical methods. As a result, iodine chemistry is often omitted from current climate models that simulate Arctic ODEs, which may significantly underestimate the rate of ozone depletion. Research Objectives: This study proposes the exploration of new technologies and methods for the selective, quantitative chemical detection of iodine compounds that may play an important role in Arctic ODEs. \end{algorithm}

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\footnotesize
\caption{Algorithm 2: Determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.}
\begin{algorithmic}[1]
\Procedure{SUCCESS}{INPUT, CLUES, REASONING}
\State $CLUES \leftarrow$ List SWOT and KAM (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references)
\State $REASONING \leftarrow$ Induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and INPUT
\State Determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and INPUT
\EndProcedure
\end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm}

\section{Summary of the main ideas of this paper}

In this paper, we have proposed an approach for determining whether the given INPUT (i.e., the research proposals submitted to NSF GRF) is a Winner or Honorable Mention considering the CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) and the REASONING process. The CLUES are generally the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations and semantic meaning which can be easily extracted from the INPUT. The REASONING process is determined from the CLUES and the INPUT. The REASONING process is based on the diagnostic reasoning process which is usually used in the decision support systems. The diagnostic reasoning process is the process to find the solutions to the problems by finding the reasons of how the given INPUT (problem) is caused by the CLUES (solution). The diagnostic reasoning process indicates the overall SUCCESS of INPUT by determining whether the INPUT

\section{Introduction}

\begin{center}\includegraphics[width=0.98\columnwidth]{abstFigure1.png}\end{center}

\section{Problem Formulation}
\label{sec:problem}

\par\noindent In this study, we attempt to tackle a two-dimensional problem (i.e., text classification problem) by focusing on the two dimensions. Our input (i.e., research proposal applications) and output (i.e., the Winner or Honorable Mention) are represented by two-dimensional data (i.e., text). In addition, we consider the input research proposal applications as input vector that is a complex structure. The input vector contains keywords, phrases, references, and all other contextual information related to the application. In the same way, the output is also represented by two-dimensional data. The output is a Winner or Honorable Mention.

\par\noindent The “input” is a research proposal

Development of a fully-automated, low-cost, near-infrared spectrometry-based device for sepsis detection and management
By: 
The global burden of sepsis is high, resulting in 1.5-5 million deaths per year. Sepsis is characterized by systemic inflammation and is linked to increased mortality, and is the most common cause of death in intensive care units (ICUs). Current sepsis management involves repeated blood draws to detect the presence of sepsis, which leads to unnecessary blood loss and hemolysis of red blood cells. Early detection of sepsis is critical for improved patient outcomes and reduced mortality; however, early detection is challenging due to the lack of a noninvasive, rapid, and inexpensive method. Near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy, which measures the interaction between light and matter, has the potential to screen for sepsis and provide continuous monitoring of inflammatory cytokines. Title: Machine Learning for Breast Cancer Prediction using Breast Tissue Metabolomics
Abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer and the second leading cause of death among women. It is estimated that 1 in 8 women will develop invasive breast cancer in her lifetime. In the gut, bacteria break down polysaccharides into health-beneficial end products of metabolism called short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) that are taken up and used for energy by host intestinal cells. The gut microbiome is an ideal model to study this type of ecosystem, as we know what nutrients these bacteria are exposed to and have access to powerful tools to study taxonomy and metabolism. Gut bacteria have been shown to break down polysaccharides in waves, with primary degrader species upregulating genes of interest at early time points, followed by secondary degraders. Research Description

Unraveling the process of polysaccharide utilization in complex bacterial ecosystems
Abstract: Bacteria do not exist in isolation in nature; they form complex communities in which they must recognize, compete over, and, share nutrient resources. The gut microbiome is an ideal model to study this type of ecosystem, as we know what nutrients these bacteria are exposed to and have access to powerful tools to study taxonomy and metabolism. Gut bacteria break down polysaccharide nutrients and convert them to health-beneficial end products of metabolism called short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) that are taken up and used for energy by host intestinal cells. However, there is a gap in our understanding of what factors give rise to the emergent phenomenon of SCFA production. Author: Sejin Shin
Abstract: Many companies are using a personality test (e.g., DISC) to predict how a candidate will fit into a particular position. However, a personality test is not perfect because it is based on a subjective judgement. In this study, we trained a classifier using natural language processing (NLP) to predict a personality trait from a text. The result shows that our model can predict a personality trait with an accuracy of 80.1%.
In this study, we trained a classifier using natural language processing (NLP) to predict a personality trait from a text. The result shows that our model can predict a personality trait with an accuracy of 80.1%.

Background
Fuel Cell provides a clean and efficient energy source for electric cars. But the commercialization of fuel cell has been hindered due to the high cost of hydrogen production. The most common way of producing hydrogen is through steam reforming of natural gas, which needs high temperature (over 700℃) and pressure (over 20MPa) to produce hydrogen. The high temperature is costly for the production of steam and hydrogen. The high pressure is required to decompose the methane into hydrogen and carbon dioxide. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a more efficient and economical way to produce hydrogen. In this project, we aim to develop a new type of fuel cell which can generate hydrogen at room temperature.

Although many technologies exist for virus particle purification, they each face unique roadblocks to developing rapid, high-yielding, and ultimately continuous processes. Chromatography is widely-used for virus purification, but suffers from low binding capacities, frequently inactivates viruses, and cannot operate continuously. Ultrafiltration is readily scalable and provides high throughput and recoveries, but fouling reduces flux and removal of contaminating proteins is often ineffective. Ultracentrifugation is difficult to scale up and has low yield, even though purities are high. Explain how you will solve the challenges you have identified in the previous section. \begin{frame}[fragile]{\frametitle{Content-based Classification of Text}
\begin{itemize}

\item Use a Feedback Loop and integrate the feedback into the learning.
\item Use the Feedback Loop to learn the latent structure and identify the source of the SUCCESS of the INPUT.
\item Use the Feedback Loop to learn the latent structure and identify the reasons for a FAILURE of the INPUT.
\end{itemize}
\end{frame}

INPUT: High-energy neutrinos are of great interest for their cosmological implications, but their detection is hindered by their low detection efficiency in current neutrino telescopes, their high background, and their short mean free path. One way to overcome these issues is to exploit the fact that neutrinos are charged particles by searching for secondary particles, produced by cosmic rays interacting in the Earth’s atmosphere. This can be accomplished in a relatively large detector with a high duty cycle, as the Earth’s atmosphere is transparent to charged particles. In particular, the area of interest for these searches is around the highest-energy cosmic rays, with energies of 10^19-10^20 eV. The Pierre Auger Observatory

RESULT: WINNER
Diemer & Kravtsov (2014) [3] demonstrated that the splashback radius is the radius where the outermost particles of the halo turn around from their first pericentric passage, also known as the caustic radius. This is the radius outside of which the total mass within the dark matter halo is approximately constant. Aun et al. (2021) [8] also predicted that the inner edge of the splashback profile is the radius where the kinematical signature of the halo turns around from its first pericentric passage. This is the radius where the internal energy of the halo first becomes negligible. The splashback radius is also the radius where the speed of the halo particles within the halo becomes negligible. The splashback radius is also the radius where the internal pressure of the halo becomes negligible. The splashback radius is also the radius where the internal pressure of the halo becomes negligible. The splashback radius

There are a few things that can be done to improve your code. First, you can use \begin{document} and \end{document} to surround your entire document. Second, the list of CLUES should be a paragraph and not a series of lines. Third, you can use \begin{display} and \end{display} to surround your code blocks. \section{The CLUES-ENRICHED Knowledge Base}
\label{sec:clues-enriched}

We have extracted and organized the CLUES from each example into a knowledge base. Each CLUES is represented as a triplet $\langle word, relation, value\rangle$. For example, the CLUES for the first example is $\langle motivation, belongs to, functional magnetic resonance imaging\rangle$. Now, we can  use these CLUES to enrich the knowledge base. For example, the CLUES for the second example is $\langle input, belongs to, research proposal submitted to NSF GRF\rangle$, $\langle input, belongs to, research proposals submitted to NSF GRF\rangle$, and $\langle input, belongs to, overall success classifier\rangle$.

\section{The Diagnostic Reasoning Process}
\label{sec:diagnostic-reasoning-process}

We have induced a diagnostic reasoning process from the CLUES and the input.

2024-05-06 13:17:43 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - Background: Protein purification is required for protein structural determination, functional studies, and biotechnology applications. The state-of-the-art approach for protein purification is by using size-exclusion chromatography (SEC). SEC is often used as a final step before crystallization to remove aggregates. Although it is a common and widely-used technique, it is not well understood at the molecular level. Recent studies indicated that the size-exclusion mechanism is dominated by the hydrophobic effect; however, to date, there are no detailed and quantitative studies on the role of hydrophobic interactions in the size-exclusion mechanism. The main objective of this work is to develop a theoretical and computational framework to understand the size-exclusion mechanism in SEC. This work is significant because it provides a fundamental understanding of the size-exclusion mechanism that can be used to design new SEC systems and improve the efficiency of protein purification. Using sample data

The input data for this contest is a CSV file which you can download by clicking the Download button on the right side of your screen. You can also view the data by clicking on the View button. The data is composed of the following columns:

- tags: a set of tags for the image, in the format of "tag1|tag2|....|tagn"
- image: a URL pointing to the image
- score: the score of the image
- competition: the competition name
- contest_id: the contest id
- image_id: the image id
- name

In this example, we use the command \renewcommand to change the meaning of the LaTeX command \chapter to add a new parameter. The new command is named \mychapter and the old command is named \chapter.

The following example shows how to use the command \renewcommand to change the meaning of the LaTeX command \chapter to make its first parameter an optional parameter. The new command is named \mychapter and the old command is named \chapter.

Note that the new command \mychapter takes an optional parameter. The optional parameter is followed by a square bracket. When the optional parameter is not used the square bracket must still be included.

Here is the example:

\documentclass{article}

\newcommand{\

1

The following solution is based on the code posted in the answer to How to draw a box around the text of all theorem-like environments?.

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{amsthm}
\usepackage{tikz}

\makeatletter
\newcommand{\setboxtheorem}{%
  \addto@hook{\th@plain}%
  \addto@hook{\th@definition}%
  \setboxtheorem@box=\hbox\bgroup}
\newcommand{\boxtheorem}{%

Research Description I will be conducting research in the field of Lie Theory, under the direction of Rob Rimanyi. A Lie algebra is a nonlinear vector space equipped with an anticommutative operation α (cid:54)= −α and a bilinear operation, [x,y] = xy − yx, called a Lie bracket. The Lie algebra is said to be semisimple if the Lie bracket is antisymmetric. If all elements of the Lie algebra are simultaneously diagonalizable, then the Lie algebra is said to be semisimple. An abelian Lie algebra is called a toral subalgebra. A subset of the Lie algebra is said to be a Cartan subalgebra if it is a maximal toral subalgebra. In particular, the Cartan subalgebra is abelian, and thus each element of the Cartan subalgebra is simultaneously ad

In the example, the PDF output looks like this,

How can I make the text wrap into the next page if it runs out of the page?

add a comment |  

up vote 1 down vote accepted

I think that the easiest thing to do is to force the text to break where is required, and then to use a package such as the multicol package for the main text. The multicol package allows you to have up to 9 columns. I have used 9 columns here to make the code easier to read. I have also added a footer. It is also possible to have a header.

To use the multicol package, you need to add the following commands around the text to be put into the multicol environment.

\usepackage{multicol}
\begin{multicols}{9}
\begin{verbatim}
...
\end{verbatim}
\end{multicols}

and these commands around the main

The source code of the proposed framework is available at \url{https://github.com/berkeley-data-science/CLUES}.

3.3 A Case Study of the CLUES Framework

To evaluate the performance of the CLUES framework, we use the research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications in four years. The prediction results, including the overall success classifier and the input examples, are shown in Table 1. The last column shows the proposed framework can predict the overall success of those applications as Winner or Honorable Mention with an accuracy of 93.75%. Most of the reasonable inputs and the related reasoning processes are shown in Table 2. We can see that the framework can identify the correct reasoning process, including the major topics, the details of the research proposals and the additional supporting information.

\begin{table}[h!]
\begin{center}
\caption{Prediction results of the CLUES framework}
\begin{tabular}{|

INTRODUCTION

The dynamics of the cytoplasm, which includes the cell chromosome and other intracellular particles is relevant to many biological processes, including cell replication and genomic control. However, these systems exist out of equilibrium and show complex dynamic behavior, not easily explained by classic dynamic theory. Recently, new fluorescent labeling techniques have allowed intracellular particles to be tracked as they move though the cell1,2. These experiments, done on E. coli, have shown that that these particles show sub-diffusive behavior. It seems that the cell environment confines the movement of these particles, and blocks them from fully exploring their surroundings. Various theories have been proposed to explain this behavior.3,4. These depend mostly on studying polymer models

Training.
A total of 205 research proposals were collected from the NSF GRF program, and preliminary results were obtained as shown in Fig. 1. The data were collected from 2012 to 2019, and the number of articles was approximately 36 per year. This research analyzed the articles based on the contents, and the number of articles was 46, 53, 43, 51, and 52 in 2012-2016, respectively. The number of articles was 46 in 2016, and the number of articles was 47 in 2017 and 2018, and 51 in 2019.
It was confirmed that it was difficult to train a machine learning model when the number of articles was small because the articles were insufficient. Therefore, a total of 205 articles were collected from 2012 to 2019, and the titles of the articles were collected.

2024-05-06 13:21:40 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \subsection{Case Study 2:  Research Proposal Evaluation (RPE)}
\subsubsection{Introduction}
The National Science Foundation  (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) supports outstanding graduate students in NSF-supported STEM disciplines who are pursuing research-based master's and doctoral degrees at accredited United States institutions. The program recognizes and supports individuals who have demonstrated their potential for significant achievements in science and engineering research. 
It is important to evaluate the quality of the research proposal (INPUT) before the awarding the GRFP. The INPUT includes the abstracts, research statements, and the CVs of the applicants for the GRFP. 
The outputs of the RPE are the quality of the INPUT and the definition of the quality of the INPUT. 
First, we list the CLUES for determining the quality of the INPUT. 
Second, we induce a diagnostic REASONING process from the CLUES and the INPUT for determining the quality of the INPUT. 
Third, we determine the

This proposal has been accepted for funding pending submission of a full proposal and successful negotiations. This manuscript is an intended outcome of the research project that the proposal is submitted for funding.

This model will allow for the isolation of the core mechanisms that underlie substance abuse, which may depend on VTA-HPC interactions. The proposed research will dissect how VTA-HPC interactions contribute to the complexity of behaviors associated with substance abuse by elucidating how both state-dependent and event-evoked interactions drive memory encoding. Even in my anecdotal experience employing active teaching techniques to engagement ees, I have found that giving individuals’ agency over minor choices, such as choosing what topic to read and discuss, and more substantial choices, such as choosing a research topic, leads to significantly more engagement and long-term retention. The proposed research will directly test how agency can affect motivation and learning at various timescales, which will contribute both to our understanding of how it can support learning and how we may utilize it to broadly enhance teaching methods.

2024-05-06 13:21:52 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \section*{Appendix}
##Introduction## The task is about the classification of NSF GRFP applications into 2 classes: Winner and Honorable Mention. The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention. 
First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.
Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.
##Input## The input is a research proposal submitted to NSF GRF applications. Input is a sequence of 130 words. Each word has a tag (positive or negative) and a score representing the degree of positive or

Funding Agency: National Science Foundation
Role: Principal Investigator
Project Summary: Catalytic NOx-Reduction with Hydrocarbons (CNH) is an important technology for the removal of harmful nitrogen oxides (NOx) from combustion exhaust gas. CNH occurs in a wide range of industrial and automotive applications, but the development of new catalysts has been hampered by the lack of effective computational approaches to predict the active sites for CNH, which is necessary for rational catalyst design. The proposed research will use machine learning (ML) methods to explore the relationship between catalyst structure and activity for CNH, with the goal of discovering new catalysts with improved activity. Success in this research program will have wide impact for refining analytical and fundamental study of the element- specific electronic structure in highly correlated materials, an extremely broad class with significant industrial, technical, and environmental relevance. Furthermore, by having fully addressed the forward problem, i.e., prediction with no adjustable parameters of ctc-XES spectra from local structure, we will be able to use unsupervised and supervised machine learning (ML) methods to understand the information content in core-to-core XES across systems already widely studied (e.g., 3d transition metals) and also systems that have seem comparatively little XES (e.g., materials with heavy d- and f-electron elements). This will likely lead to prediction of new diagnostic spectral signatures of magnetism in f-electron systems.

Hypothesis: The study of twins will help to isolate the effect of the learning environment from the genetic component. The below is the output.

Conclusion

To summarize, writing a winning NSF GRFP essay is a hard task. There is no doubt that you need a strong writing skill and a conceptual understanding of the scientific procedure. However, the idea is that you have to write an essay that stands out from the crowd. Through this answer, I have tried to give some guidelines that might help you to write an effective essay. Please let me know if you have other ideas to help future applicants. If you want to customize the above code, feel free to contact me. I can provide you the latex code for the same.

Fig. 4. The training dataset for the research problem of the overall success classifier is composed of research proposals submitted to NSF GRFP (i.e., Winner or Honorable Mention). In this dataset, the each research proposal is represented by the title and the linguistic information extracted from the title. The overall success is the Winner or Honorable Mention. The overall success classifier is a deep learning based classifier that determines the overall success of the research proposal.

Fig. 5. The linguistic information extracted from the research proposal is the combination of the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones and references. The linguistic information for the research proposal is represented by the neural network model and we call this information as CLUES. The overall success of the research proposal is determined by the diagnostic reasoning process from CLUES and the research proposal.

The evaluation of the reason for success of a research proposal is a complex problem that involves many factors. As we have seen in the past, the complexity of the factors involved in a research proposal and the significant amount of computational resources required for such an analysis make it difficult to find a solution to this problem. Therefore, it is important that the research community produce more studies that can be used to validate the effectiveness of research proposal evaluation methods. In addition, it is important to create a system that can be used to provide a more objective evaluation of the research proposal without relying on the experience of a single person. It is an interesting idea and I think it is possible to implement in the context of dialog modeling. However, I think the current paper is not ready for submission to CLIPS. This is because there are too many assumptions and the paper is not well written. I will point out some things that I personally felt were problematic.

- I think the first sentence of the motivation section should be edited. Right now you are saying you are modeling the input as a sequence. In the next paragraph your model is a sequence to sequence model. I don't think it really makes sense to do both.
- I don't think you need this many references in the introduction. I would remove all of the references except the final one. If you cite the final one in the introduction, there is no need to reference it again later in the paper.
- I think the motivation should be placed before the introduction.

The core idea of DIAGNOSIS-GRF is to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT using CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.
Therefore, we induce the REASONING process for INPUT using CLUES.
First, we determine the CLUES of INPUT using the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, and tones.
Second, we determine the CLUES of INPUT using the references.
Third, we determine the CLUES of INPUT using the semantic relations.
Fourth, we induce the REASONING process for INPUT using the CLUES.
Fifth, we determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

\section{Introduction}
\begin{itemize}
\item This is a classification task to identify whether the applicant will be winner or honorable mention in NSF GRFP.
\item The research proposal is the input.
\item The research proposal is the overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention.
\item 1. list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.
\item 2. induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
\item 3. determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.
\end{itemize}

DREAM Challenge: Recognizing the overall SUCCESS of the NSF GRFP applications by detecting CLUES from research proposals 
Published by Shuhei Yamada on February 19, 2018
This challenge is similar to the previous but different in the following 1) The research proposals are from the NSF GRF program. 2) The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention. 3) First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT. 4) Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130). 5) Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING

REASONING PROCESS:
The overall SUCCESS of INPUT is Honorable Mention. 
The reasoning process of overall SUCCESS is the LOSS of RESULT by FAILURE and the WIN of RESULT by WIN.
The CLUES are the LOSS of RESULT by FAILURE and the WIN of RESULT by WIN to determine the overall SUCCESS.
The LOSS of RESULT by FAILURE is the decrease in redox potential and the increase in the oxidation rate. The WIN of RESULT by WIN is the increase in redox potential and the decrease in the oxidation rate.
The REDOX is the determination of oxidizing or reducing and the DEPTH is the determination of the surface or below the surface.
The REDOX and DEPTH are the LOSS of RESULT by FAILURE and the WIN of RESULT by WIN to determine the overall SUCCESS.
The REDOX

Title: A new approach to identify the optimal number of clusters

Author: Richard C. Johnson, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

Date: 2018-04-18

Abstract: A new approach to identify the optimal number of clusters in a data set based on the L2 distance between the cluster centers is proposed. The new approach is compared to the classical Bayesian information criterion (BIC) and the classical Schwarz information criterion (SC). The new approach is shown to have a better predictive power in identifying the number of clusters than BIC and SC.

Keywords: K-means, clustering, BIC, SC, L2 distance.

Background: The L2 distance between the cluster centers is a measure of the overall distance between cluster centers and it is used to define the distance between two clusters. The objective of this work is to propose a new approach to estimate the optimal number of clusters in a data set

The reason for success: There is a positive correlation between redox potential and potential oxidation rate. The redox potential and potential oxidation rate will be highest in the rhizosphere relative to the rest of the water column in open-water sedge sites.
The reason for failure: There is no positive correlation between redox potential and potential oxidation rate. The redox potential and potential oxidation rate will not be highest in the rhizosphere relative to the rest of the water column in open-water sedge sites.

Lecture1
Thawing permafrost is a major concern in permafrost regions as it releases greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and increases the risk of coastal flooding. The most significant greenhouse gas released from thawing permafrost is methane (CH4), which is 34 times as powerful as CO2. The rate of CH4 release from thawing permafrost soils is uncertain because of a lack of information about the state of the peat in the soils. Recent studies have shown that CH4 release can be reduced by increasing the amount of water in the soils, which can be achieved by increasing the soil water content. Poster 2
Identify the key words that have the strongest impact on specific features of a student’s transcript and then use these keywords to infer a student’s academic performance.
The inputs are a student’s transcript (i.e., all courses taken by a student and the credits taken by a student), and the outputs are the academic performance of the student.
First, collect the words of the transcript, e.g., words of a course title.
Second, extract the key words from the words that appear the most frequently in the transcript.
Third, identify the keywords that have the strongest impact on specific features of a student’s transcript.
The third step determines the keywords that have the strongest impact on specific features of a student’s transcript, e.g., the keywords that have the strongest impact on the number of credits taken by the student.
Fourth, infer the academic performance of the student by using the keywords.

Abstract: 
The application data of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) are used to identify the temporary success of early career scientists. The temporal success of the data was modeled by a two-stage random structure, in which the first stage was the reason for a successful proposal and the second stage was the success of a successful proposal. The first stage was modeled by a discrete choice model, and the second stage was modeled by a random zero-inflated model. The process of the two-stage random structure was tested through simulated data. In the simulation, the information about the reason for success and the success of success was simulated. The two-stage random structure was used to analyze the data of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) for the first time. The results show that the two-stage random structure can be used to model the reasons for success. The first-stage model can provide a more reasonable

2024-05-06 13:25:47 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - RESULTS: The results show that Coral reefs provide services totaling $10 trillion despite covering only ~0.3% of the ocean floor1. Their evolutionary success relies on the association between coral animals and symbiotic algae. Corals provide shelter and nutrients for symbionts which in turn supply sugars and O to their hosts2. Corals host symbionts within the symbiosome, an intracellular space 2 defined by the coral-derived symbiosome membrane. This membrane is thought to allow corals to regulate delivery of nutrients to the symbiont but the specific transport mechanisms are mostly unknown. Alarmingly, human-caused ocean warming, acidification, and eutrophication disrupt this symbiosis leading to the expulsion of symbionts (known as ‘bleaching’), decreased coral fitness, and death2. However, the lack of mechanistic knowledge of healthy symbiosis impairs our ability to understand why bleaching occurs, identify resilient and vulnerable species, and design conservation strategies. The

A comparative analysis of the putative role of SCMP 2 in the endocytic iterative cycle in humans and the apicomplexan parasite Toxoplasma gondii.
INPUT: SCMP2 is a component of the endocytic iterative cycle in humans and is therefore a potential drug target for the treatment of cancer or neurological disorders. There are no known studies of the function of SCMP2 in other species. Since Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes brain infection and has a complex life cycle involving both the mammalian and the avian hosts, we hypothesize that SCMP2 is essential for the parasite’s survival and replication in the host. We thus compared the protein structure and the gene organization of the SCMP2 orthologs in T. gondii and humans to identify possible differences that might explain their different functions.

2024-05-06 13:26:27 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Although the mechanisms underlying the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are not fully elucidated, accumulating evidence shows that tau pathology, in part, underlies AD (Goedert et al., Nature 2017, Wang et al. Nat Neurosci 2018). Tau pathology is characterized by the accumulation of intracellular neurofibrillary tangles comprised of abnormal hyperphosphorylated tau (NFL/Phospho-tau, p-tau) (Goedert et al., Nature 2017, Wang et al. Nat Neurosci 2018). Tau protein is a microtubule-associated protein (MAP) that binds to the microtubule cytoskeleton to promote microtubule assembly and stability (Bolós et al. Nat Rev Neurosci 2017). It also plays a role in intracellular vesicle trafficking and presynaptic neurotransmitter release (Bolós et al. Nat Rev Neurosci 2017). Tau

2024-05-06 13:26:30 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - RESULT: The evolution of similar traits in distantly related species is one of nature’s great surprises. Convergent evolution of traits has been widely observed throughout the animal kingdom; however, it is often unclear whether this phenotypic convergence results from convergent evolution of genes (Stern, Nat Rev Genet 2013). On a molecular level, convergent evolution occurs when the amino acids of a specific protein preferentially undergo mutations that produce similar or even identical amino acid sequences within distinct evolutionary lineages. A high level of adaptive convergent evolution – that is, convergence due to positive selection of beneficial mutations – would suggest that some genes have “optimal configurations,” which evolution uses and reuses across species. If such genes exist, then evolution is somewhat predictable, proceeding by one of a small number of possible paths (Stern & Orgogozo, Science 2008). In contrast, a complete absence of adaptive convergence would indicate that protein configurations beneficial to one species are seldom optimal within other

Convergent evolution of traits has been widely observed throughout the animal kingdom; however, it is often unclear whether this phenotypic convergence results from convergent evolution of genes (Stern, Nat Rev Genet 2013). Research Proposal-Sublimation of a Sulfide Glass

Posted on March 18, 2019 by sarah

Sublimation of a Sulfide Glass

Researcher: Vishnu Muthukrishnan

Abstract: Our goal is to sublimate a sulfide glass Sb2S3 and understand the mechanism of sublimation. The aim is to produce Sb2S3 at high purity and understand the mechanism of sublimation. By understanding the mechanism of sublimation we will be able to control the deposition of a sulfide glass on a substrate and understand how the sublimation can be used as an alternative method to prepare thin films.

Research Plan: Sb2S3 is an interesting material with many potential applications. It is a semiconductor and can be used as a transparent conductor, a therm

All the above works by using keywords and text mining methods. The proposed method is a combination of natural language processing and knowledge based reasoning. This method is a promising approach to improve the overall success in research proposals. This approach will be applied to a series of research in the area of natural language processing and knowledge based reasoning.

~ Kevin Michael Wyss

Generating Textual Description for a Disease

01/04/2020 | 0 Comments
Abstract: A disease has many characteristics, and we often need to describe a disease using its characteristics. For example, a doctor may describe a disease using its characteristics, such as nausea, fever, or vomiting. Therefore, it is necessary to generate textual description for a disease. In this study, we propose a neural network-based method to generate a textual description of a disease given its characteristics. Our approach is based on a neural network that uses the characteristics as input, and the textual description as output. This algorithm has been tested on a publicly available dataset of 12,000 cases. The results show that our approach can generate a textual description of a disease.

The structure of INPUT is as follows:

- [1], a major gap still exists between the skills of these graduates and the skills needed for industry success [2].
- Two major components of this gap are programming skills (e.g. code style) and computational thinking (e.g. extending algorithms).
- My research will enable teachers to close these gaps by building a toolkit to integrate better-targeted problem types than those currently in use.
- Programming assignments in CS classrooms, primarily code tracing and code writing, lack the granularity to target students’ Zones of Proximal Development (ZPD, i.e. challenging but solvable problems). Code tracing questions involve reading and understanding code, but they may not trigger students’ mental models of concepts because they are tedious or too easy [3, 4].
- Code writing questions are a large leap from code tracing, conflating many programming skills into a single solution (e.g. design, computational thinking, programming, code style)

The arctic sea ice cover is a complex and vital component of the earth system, and the rate of its loss in recent decades has been important to observe and study. In this paper, we apply a novel method to the analysis of satellite-observed Arctic sea ice cover to show that the influence of the changing climate on the sea ice cover is complex, and is likely to continue to be so. We provide a simple graphical representation of the results that is suitable for use in a public forum. We discuss the implications of the results on the reduction of sea ice cover in the Arctic. \section{Introduction}

\IEEEPARstart{I}{nvestigators} in the field of Computational Thinking claim that teaching Computational Thinking (CT) is key for educating students for the 21st century economies and professions \cite{craig2016computational}. CT allows students to understand and use fundamental concepts of computer science, such as problem decomposition, abstraction, algorithm design and implementation, and data structures. Emphasis is placed on higher-order thinking skills, such as decomposition, abstraction, and algorithm design, which are often underrepresented in traditional pedagogy \cite{craig2016computational}.

The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) data shows that approximately 50\% of applicants in U.S. Colleges and Universities apply for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) majors. However, the

Example 2: Research Plan for a Synthetic Biology Project (from the SARS-CoV-2 example)

This is an example of a research plan for a synthetic biology project. The inputs are proposals submitted to the NSF ABI FASTER program and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention. 
First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.
Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

INPUT: [1], a major gap still exists between the skills of these graduates and the skills needed for industry success [2]. Two major components of this gap are programming skills (e.g. code style) and computational thinking (e.g. extending algorithms). My research will enable teachers to close these gaps by building a toolkit to integrate better-targeted problem types than those currently in use. Programming assignments in CS classrooms, primarily code tracing and code writing, lack the granularity to target students’ Zones of Proximal Development (ZPD, i.e. challenging but solvable problems). Code tracing questions involve reading and understanding code, but they may not trigger students’ mental models of concepts because they are tedious or too easy [3, 4]. \end{tabular}

\end{table}

This is the tool proposed for the first stage of the process. The tool should be able to identify the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references and list them as CLUES.

HONORABLE MENTION: honorable mention

In our model, the INPUT is the text of the research proposal, REASONING is the reasoning process, and CLUES is the clues. 
The CLUES includes the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, and tones. 
The REASONING is the reasoning process of the CLUES. 
The OUTPUT is the winner or honorable mention. 
The INPUT, REASONING, and CLUES are given to our model, and then OUTPUT is determined.

\subsection{Contextual Information}

Contextual information is used to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.

OUTPUT: Winner or Honorable Mention

\subsection{Classification of overall SUCCESS}
\label{subsection:classification_of_overall_success}
The classification of overall SUCCESS is to determine whether the INPUT is a Winner or an Honorable Mention.
In this classification, the CLUES, REASONING process and the INPUT are used as inputs and the overall SUCCESS is used as the output.
To obtain the CLUES, we have to consider the two related tasks. 
First, we have to identify the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, and references in the INPUT.
Second, we have to build the REASONING process from these CLUES.
Next, we have to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT taking the CLUES, REASONING process and the INPUT into account.

\section{Reinforcement Learning}
\label{RL}
\begin{figure*}[ht]
  \centering
  \includegraphics[width=0.9\linewidth]{RL.png}
  \caption{Knowledge graph embedding framework for reinforcement learning. In the input, the REINFORCEMENT LEARNING process is \textit{determining the probability of the overall SUCCESS} based on the CLUES and the INPUT. }
  \label{fig:RL}
\end{figure*}

In this section, we introduce a reinforcement learning framework for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT based on CLUES. The learning is based on text information in the INPUT. The CLUES are the research proposals of NSF GRF applications. The INPUT is a research proposal to NSF GRF application. The REINFORCEMENT LEARNING process is \textit{determining the probability of the overall SUCCESS} based on the CLUES and

The challenge is to develop an algorithm that can determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT, considering CLUES and REASONING, and the INPUT. The algorithm may be developed using non-neural network methods or neural network methods. The algorithm may be developed using any language, including any natural language, artificial language, or any combination of natural language and artificial language. The algorithm may be developed using any programming language, including any programming language that can be executed on any platform or in any application.

The input, CLUES, REASONING, and output are text. Text is defined as text that is contained within a block of text. A block of text is defined as a block of characters that is delimited by whitespace or a delimiter that is not a whitespace character. A whitespace character is a space, regular tab, or other character that is used for indentation and line breaks. The input is a block of

RESULT: Winner, Honorable Mention

The first step is to list CLUES for determining the overall success of INPUT.
The second step is to induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
The third step is to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

In the present disclosure, the first step of the PROCESS for generating the CLUES for determining the overall SUCCESS (WINNER or HONORABLE MENTION) of INPUT is to collect from the INPUT keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references, etc., and then to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT considering these CLUES and the INPUT.

Let us consider a research proposal and a human evaluation as INPUT for understanding the overall SUCCESS process. The research proposal is to develop a new method of a data-driven AI, and the human evaluation is to determine the overall SUCCESS of the proposal as Winner or Honorable Mention. The CLUES are keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references, and they are induced from the research proposal. The CLUES are used for the REASONING process for determining the overall SUCCESS of the research proposal. The REASONING process is represented by a dependency tree diagram for describing the CLUES and the research proposal. The REASONING process is used to determine the overall SUCCESS of the research proposal as Winner or Honorable Mention.

The OUTPUT is displayed through a table.

The input includes the text (i.e., research paper) and the keywords and references (i.e., CLUES). The CLUES are extracted automatically using the tool [5,6]. The keyword extraction method is based on Chinese Word Segmentation (CWS) and Maximum Entropy (ME) [5]. The reference extraction method is based on CWS and Maximum Matching (MM) [6].

The output includes the analysis result (i.e., Winner or Honorable Mention).

The analysis result is displayed through a graph using the tool [5].

The classifier includes 1) ensemble of learning algorithms, 2) classifier selection, 3) ensemble selection, 4) parameter optimization and 5) evaluation. The classifier is evaluated by accuracy and F1 score

\begin{algorithm}[tb]
\caption{The proposed neural architecture for the overall SUCCESS classification.}
\label{alg1}
\begin{algorithmic}[1]
\STATE {INPUT: text $\leftarrow$ text for GRF}
\STATE {CLUES: keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references $\leftarrow$ all clue words, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references}
\STATE {REASONING PROCESS $\leftarrow$ diagnostic reasoning process from CLUES and INPUT}
\STATE {SUCCESS: Winner or Honorable Mention $\leftarrow$ Winner or Honorable Mention of INPUT}
\end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm}

I think there is a problem with the way you are using the \begin{document} command. The document class is not loaded before \begin{document}. – karlkoeller Aug 29 '14 at 5:50

     

@karlkoeller : I took the document class out and it worked thank you. – user42389 Aug 29 '14 at 6:00

     

Shouldn't the job be done by the compiler (pdflatex), in fact? – user11232 Aug 29 '14 at 6:25

     

There is a problem with your code. The document class is not loaded before \begin{document}. Please, always put your code between \begin{document} and \end{document}. – karlkoeller Aug 29 '14 at 6:25

2024-05-06 13:31:20 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results -     Fig.1. Workflow for project. (a) Each factor will be varied systematically to optimize the microarray (b) After optimization, the exosome sample will be applied to the microarray spots, and wash, blocking, and drying steps will be performed. After binding only the functionalized exosomes, the spots will be read for relative fluorescence, which is compared to the standard to determine the concentration of functionalized exosomes. (c) Once a standard is established, a variety of engineering strategies could be tested. The exosomes in each culture medium will be quantified by applying them to the microarray spots and reading relative fluorescence. The microarray will enable comparison of multiple samples in a single experiment. (d) Comparison of results to standard will determine the best conditions for exosome production. (e) The final workflow will include comparison of the microarray results to the standard for situating the conditions in the proper range.

Exosomes are a type of nano-sized extracellular vesicle (EV) naturally produced by cells and released via endosomal fusion with the plasma membrane. Although primarily utilized in the detection of diseases such as cancer, exosomes are increasingly being investigated as a means of drug delivery due to their potential for multi-functional targeting and inherent biocompatibility [1]. A longstanding setback in the study and application of exosomes for therapeutic purposes is the lack of standardized methods with which to isolate, concentrate, and characterize them [2]. The logistic regression classifier has an AUC of 0.73.  We are not interested in the overall success classifier, but the precision and recall of the Winner and Honorable Mention classification.  The precision and recall of the Winner classification is 0.50 and 0.29, respectively.  The precision and recall of the Honorable Mention classification is 0.09 and 0.23, respectively.  This shows that the overall success classifier does not work, so we need to develop a new classifier.  We developed two models. Protein microarrays can be modified to include different antibodies in each spot. The ideal formulation would be one that binds only targeted exosomes. Exosomes express the surface ligands CD9, CD63, and CD81 as unique identifiers from other EVs [3]. Antibody cocktails for these ligands, as well as the expressed targeting molecules, would enable binding of only the desired exosomes— even in the presence of a crude EV sample—while washing away all other materials in solution. I will determine the concentration of each antibody for optimal exosome binding kinetics, which is a function of the desired targeting molecule antibody. INPUT: Introduction: Development of personalized medical treatments and diagnostics is limited by our ability to engineer tools that can keep up with demand. Exosomes are a type of nano-sized extracellular vesicle (EV) naturally produced by cells and released via endosomal fusion with the plasma membrane. Although primarily utilized in the detection of diseases such as cancer, exosomes are increasingly being investigated as a means of drug delivery due to their potential for multi-functional targeting and inherent biocompatibility [1]. A longstanding setback in the study and application of exosomes for therapeutic purposes is the lack of standardized methods with which to isolate, concentrate, and characterize them [2]. Although scientists can functionalize exosomes with targeting molecules and drug payloads, scale-up is limited by the ability to quickly identify favorable processing conditions and thus good manufacturing practices. In this project, I propose creating a system that will reduce the burden of the screening process by developing a tool to rapidly assess exosome production and functionality

Régime sans gluten : la maladie coeliaque

Diabète, hypercholestérolémie, maladie de Crohn et insuffisance rénale chez le sujet âgé : les facteurs de risque influencent-ils le bénéfice du régime sans gluten ?

Celiac disease is an immune-mediated enteropathy caused by intolerance to dietary gluten. In genetically predisposed individuals, ingestion of gluten leads to an immune response that affects the small intestine and is associated with malabsorption. The disease is associated with osteopenia, anemia, short stature, delayed puberty, small bowel lymphoma, and an increased risk for other autoimmune diseases. Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, with a high prevalence of iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency

\begin{abstract}The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention.

First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.

Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).

Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

\end{abstract}
\end{document}

\subsection{Characteristics of the Proposed Method}

The overall success classifier is based on the input, the research proposal. The input is a raw text of the research proposal, and the researchers or students have to write the research proposal for the application of NSF GRFP. The proposed method can help to determine the overall success of the research proposal (Winner or Honorable Mention). The proposed method has the following characteristics.
\begin{itemize}
    \item The proposed method is an automatic method without human labels.
    \item The proposed method is a text classification method which is a supervised learning method.
    \item The proposed method is a deep learning method which

The CLUES are Keywords, Introduction, Experimental design, Anticipated results, and References.
DIAGNOSTIC REASONING: The REASONING process is determined from the CLUES and INPUT considering the following.
1. The REASONING process: The overall SUCCESS is Winner or Honorable Mention. The Winner is the one whose the REASONING process is the Winner and the Honorable Mention is the one whose the REASONING process is the Honorable Mention.
2. The INPUT: The INPUT is the classification by the Winner or Honorable Mention of the Applicants to the Winner or Honorable Mention.
3. The CLUES: The CLUES are Keywords, Introduction, Experimental design, Anticipated results, and References.
The DIAGNOSTIC REASONING process is the following.

\subsection{Overall Progress}
\label{subsec:overall_progress}
The goal of this study is to investigate the research area of \emph{wireless power transfer via strongly coupled magnetic resonances}.\footnote{Reflexive Field Containment in Dynamic Inductive Power Transfer Systems, November 2014} The overall progress of this study is as follows.
\begin{itemize}
    \item Stage I: The initial investigations are based on the reflexive field containment compensation approach \cite{reflexive_field_containment_2014}, which achieves field containment by exploiting the receiving coil’s reflected capacitive reactance to neutralize the source coil’s inductive reactance. 
    It is also called reflexive resonance. The source coil’s current is thus attenuated when the coils are uncoupled, thereby reducing emanated fields. 
    The high power multi-coil wireless power transfer system is also called a transformer.
    \item Stage

\end{document}

I am getting the following error.

ERROR: Paragraph ended before \@@verbatim@ was complete.

--- TeX said ---

See the LaTeX manual or LaTeX Companion for explanation.
Type  H <return>  for immediate help.
 ...                                              

l.68 \end{verbatim}

How can I fix this?

formatting verbatim

2 Answers 

up vote 7 down vote accepted

You can't use verbatim in the argument to another command. You need to change the definition of \problem to:

\newcommand{\problem}[1]{\begin{center}
\textbf{#1}
\end{center}}

and then use \problem rather than \begin{verbatim}.

share|improve this answer

answered Jun 28 '12 at 8:15

Ian Thompson
18.8k3276

add a comment | 

up vote 6 down vote

However, in social science research, researchers often collect data in the form of survey responses, which are categorical rather than quantitative. Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaire’s disease, has only recently become a human pathogen. Its intracellular lifecycle in amoeba, the natural host, has primed the bacteria for invasion into human alveolar macrophages. Co-evolution within amoeba and horizontal gene transfer has helped shape the near 300 effectors produced by Legionella that are injected into the host cell by the Dot/Icm type IVB translocation system1. A majority of these effectors have eukaryotic-like domains such as: F-box, U-box, Sel-1, ankyrin repeats, leucine- rich repeats, and CaaX motifs, which were likely acquired by horizontal gene transfer2. These domains aid in the hijacking of host processes by L. pneumophila in order to promote growth and replication.

The keywords that are given a score of 5 are positive keywords and are given a weight of 0.5. The keywords that are given a score of 1 are negative keywords and are given a weight of -0.5. Indeed, brain activity during REM sleep is similar to that during waking, and REM sleep after learning is important for memory consolidation. \section{Results}
\subsection{Classifiers}
\label{sec:results}
We will use the following classifiers for our analysis. We will use this classifier in combination with the other classifiers of the next section. We will compare their performance with each other and against the baseline. We will also use these classifiers as the baseline for the following classifiers. The classifiers are:
\begin{itemize}
\item SVM (Support Vector Machine) classifier from Weka~\cite{Weka} with a default parameter~\cite{SVMWeka} with a linear kernel.
\item Random Forest (RF) classifier from Weka with default parameters.
\item Logistic Regression (LR) classifier from Weka with default parameters.
\item Naive Bayes (NB) classifier from Weka with a default parameter~\cite{Weka} with a Gaussian kernel.
\end{itemize}

We will use the following additional classifiers in the following section:

My research will explore a method that uses an algorithm called Support Vector Machines (SVM) to classify patients and healthy controls from Electroencephalogram (EEG) data. It will be evaluated on its accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. \section{The overall classification process}

The overall classification process is summarized in Algorithm \ref{alg:overall}. The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention. 
First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.
Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

\begin{algorithm}
\floatname{algorithm}{Algorithm}
\caption{Overall classification process}
\label

The overall success classifier is implemented as a pure function (i.e., {\tt Getter}) and it is called as below.

`Getter[results, 0, 2]`

When the overall success of {\tt results} is the Winner, then the output of this function is 2.

As a result, the overall success is Winner ({\tt results[[1]]}) for {\tt results}.

The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRFP. This is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention.

First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT.

Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).

Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES

\section{Conclusion}
This paper presents the CLUES of overall SUCCESS of INPUT and a diagnostic REASONING process to determine overall SUCCESS of INPUT based on CLUES and the INPUT. This approach is specific to the research proposals for the NSF GRF and the NSF GRFP. The CLUES can be reused for other success classifiers.
