That is not ideal at all. It is far from ideal to have to reformat the LaTeX code and to have to manually add comments to the LaTeX file to make it work as a single sentence. I have tried the following:

- Using the command \typein [\COMMENT{}]{Comment to add to the code:} after each code line. This does not work.
- Using the package verbatim. It does not work either.
- Using the environment comment. It does not work either.

The only package that works is comment: it simply ignores the whole code and only shows the comment. But this is not what I want. I want the code to be formatted as a single sentence, but to have the comment to be show only if the user wishes so.

What is the best way to do this? I am looking for a solution that does not require too much work to be implemented on an existing document. I have tried to
2024-05-06 13:38:55 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$
2024-05-06 13:38:55 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: retry 9
2024-05-06 13:38:56 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:38:57 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \end{multicols}
\end{document}

This is the problem:

- The text runs over the page border.
- There is a big whitespace after the \begin{multicols} command.

I don't know how to get rid of the whitespace and I haven't found a solution on the web.

add comment

up vote 4 down vote accepted

The problem is that multicols has to insert page breaks at certain places to accommodate the page length. It tries to work out where it can fit the columns on the page and inserts \clearpage before \begin{multicols} to make sure there is room for the columns. If you want to remove the whitespace you need to tell multicols that it can place the columns on the page anywhere. You can do this by setting the longest column to be the same width as the textwidth.

\documentclass[12pt,a4paper]{article}
\usepackage{graphicx}
\usepackage{mult

The input of the WINNER/HONORABLE MENTION classifier is a research proposal submitted to NSF GRF. The output of this classifier is WINNER or HONORABLE MENTION. We have evaluated two methods for this classifier: (1) A semantic information based method and (2) A semantic information based method plus a diagnostic reasoning method. In this section, we discuss the results of the two methods. 

\subsection{Method 1: A Semantic Information Based Method}
In this method, we have applied a semantic information processing method for determining the overall success. The semantic information processing is a diagnostic reasoning process. We determine the success of the research proposal by applying a diagnostic reasoning process to the semantic information associated with the research proposal. In this method, we assume that the semantic information associated with the research proposal is sufficient for determining the overall success. 2024-05-06 13:40:11 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Algorithmic improvements for the generation of Nash equilibria by defining the set of strategies that keep the player safe Keywords: Algorithmic Game Theory, Nash Equilibrium, Computational Game Theory, Pseudorandomness. Introduction Nash equilibrium is a central concept in the study of games. In a game, two or more participants each choose a strategy from a set of available options. An outcome of a game is a tuple of strategies (one for each player) that is a solution to the associated underlying optimization problem. The outcome is defined to be a Nash equilibrium if each player is doing the best that can be done given what the others are doing. An illustrative example is a game where each player is playing a game of chess against an opponent. In this game, each player will choose the chess piece they will move and the square that they will move to; the outcome is a game of chess. The Nash equilibrium is when each player is playing the best move they can given what the other

In the study of natural language decision making, the focus is typically on the decision itself, but what about the words that come before the decision? These words may contain important information, as natural language processing (NLP) has shown that each word has a vector representation with semantic meaning. For example, the word “Tiger” is seen as a predator that attacks its prey such as “Wild Animal” or “Puma” whereas the word “Lion” is related to “King” or “Animal” (i.e., “The King of Animals”). This channel can be represented as a cycle graph G in which each vertex represents a transmitted symbol and each edge indicates indistinguishability between symbols. A cycle graph is a graph which consists of a single cycle, i.e. a series of vertices connected in a loop. For instance, the cycle graph C (shown in 5 Fig. 1 with one of its independent sets in blue) represents a communication channel with five distinct symbols (herein called a, b, c, d, and e) in which adjacent symbols can be mistaken for each other due to noise in the channel. Algorithms are the core of all computer science, and can be used to solve a wide variety of problems. Despite the growing importance of algorithms in computing, there is no consistent way to teach them to students. 2024-05-06 13:40:29 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: A New Mathematical Model and an Algorithm for the Traveling Tournament Problem Keywords: Traveling Tournament Problem, Mathematical Model, Algorithm Introduction The traveling tournament problem is a variant of the traveling salesperson problem first introduced by Jacques Herbrand [1] in 1922. The traveling tournament problem is a class of traveling salesman problems in which the objective is to minimize the number of tournaments that need to be staged in order for each team to play every other team once. The traveling tournament problem is a multi-commodity flow problem, which is the most general class of traveling salesman problems. An example of a traveling tournament problem is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1. An example of a traveling tournament problem. The Traveling Tournament Problem is a variant of the Traveling Salesperson Problem. This channel can be represented as a cycle graph G in which each vertex represents a transmitted symbol and each edge indicates indistinguishability between symbols. A cycle graph is a graph which consists of a single cycle, i.e. a series of vertices connected in a loop. For instance, the cycle graph C (shown in 5 Fig. 1 with one of its independent sets in blue) represents a communication channel with five distinct symbols (herein called a, b, c, d, and e) in which adjacent symbols can be mistaken for each other due to noise in the channel. 2024-05-06 13:40:43 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Improving the Robustness of the LSB Algorithm Keywords: LSB, Robustness, Steganography Introduction Steganography is the practice of hiding a message within an image. The message is usually encrypted, and is therefore undetectable by the naked eye. The least significant bit (LSB) algorithm is a widely known and used technique. In the LSB algorithm, the least significant bits of the pixels in the image are modified. This is done by swapping the least significant bit of the pixel with the least significant bit of the corresponding message. To ensure that the message is not detectable, the LSB algorithm is often combined with an encryption algorithm. Proposal The goal of this project is to make the LSB algorithm more robust to attacks. The LSB algorithm is vulnerable to simple attacks such as flipping pixels. In order to make the LSB algorithm more robust, we need to find a way in which flipping a pixel is not enough to reveal the message. Intellectual Merit This project will have broad

While there are many benefits to online learning, there are still many questions regarding how to best approach it. This project will focus on the effects of online math instruction videos and will be published as a paper in an academic journal. Proposal I will collect data from students who have used online math videos (specifically Khan Academy) and compare them to students who did not use online videos. 2024-05-06 13:40:58 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Learning Stein Variational Gradient Descent from Neural Networks Keywords: Stein Variational Gradient Descent, Neural Networks, Information Bottleneck Theory, Inference and Learning Introduction Variational Inference is a widely used family of algorithms for learning models from data. Inference algorithms such as Mean Field Variational Bayes (MFVB) and Stochastic Variational Bayes (SVB) are widely used in parameter learning. However, these algorithms do not construct a model, but rather a distribution over it. It is known that if the model is greedy, i.e. only one variable is non zero at each iteration, then the resulting distribution is a good approximation to the true model. This is an important concept known as the Information Bottleneck (IB) Principle. The main idea of IB is to choose a distribution, and then try to minimize the mutual information of that distribution with the data. In this proposal we want to use neural networks for learning a greedy model, and then use IB to construct

Figure 1. Overall Success prediction process of the research proposal.

Note: Figure 1 is a simplified version of the process. The process includes three major components (a) CLUES, (b) REASONING process, (c) INPUTS. CLUES are the keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT. REASONING process is the diagnostic reasoning process for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT. INPUT is the research proposal submitted to NSF GRF applications. Figure 1 shows that the three major components are integrated to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT (WINNER or HONORABLE MENTION).

\subsection{Additional Information}
\label{sec:additional_info}

The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF FFRDC applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention.
The CLUES used are the research proposal and the peers' review.
The REASONING used is the peer's review be the base of the DIAGNOSTIC REASONING.
The overall SUCCESS is Winner or Honorable Mention.
The overall SUCCESS of INPUT is based on CLUES, the REASONING and the INPUT.

2024-05-06 13:41:40 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - Figure 1: The framework for the decision support system and the success classification model. 

The framework of the decision support system is shown in Figure 1. The framework consists of the following three steps: (1) list clues, (2) induce reasoning process, and (3) determine success. The input is the research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and the output is the overall success of the applicants. The first step, list clues, is the process to determine the clues for the success classification. The clues are the explicit and implicit information embedded in the research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications. The list of clues include the keywords and phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, and tones. The second step, induce reasoning process, is the process to construct the diagnostic reasoning process to determine the overall success. The overall success of the applicants is the Winner or Honorable Mention. In this case, the Winner is the overall success of the applicants and the Honorable Mention

\subsection{Evaluation of the Classifier}
The overall success rate of the classifier is $67\%$ and the precision, recall and F1 score is given by $0.65$, $0.58$ and $0.62$ respectively. The confusion matrix is given in Table \ref{table:confusion_matrix}. The analysis of the confusion matrix indicates that our classifier has a tendency to classify the applications that receive Honorable Mention as Winner. In the following sections, we analyze the proposed method based on the results of the classifier.

REASONING: 
Arctic ozone depletion events (ODEs) are associated with elevated concentrations of halogenated radicals. Bromine is the primary driver of ODEs. Iodine chemistry is not well understood. Bromine chemistry dominates Arctic ODEs; even small perturbations in the iodine concentration significantly impact the rate of ozone depletion. Bromine chemistry doubles the efficiency of ozone depletion.

\section{CONCLUSION}

This is for good reason: causal inference is a technique for identifying the precise impact of a given intervention on the target outcome, which is essentially impossible otherwise due to issues of confounding. We see this everywhere from MPRA estimated gene expression not predicting measured expression in cells [1] to the numerous nudges that work well in laboratories and fail when scaled [2]. 2.2.2.1. CLUES

As shown in Table 1, the CLUES are: (1) keywords, (2) phrases, (3) contextual information, (4) semantic relations, (5) semantic meaning, and (6) tones. For keywords, the keywords are the most important words in the INPUT. The keywords form the core of the INPUT, so we will discuss them in the next section. For phrases, phrases are composed of keywords and other words. The phrases represent the undergraduate level of the INPUT. For contextual information, contextual information includes any information that is related to the INPUT, such as the author’s name, the journal title, the year of the paper, etc. The contextual information is the high-school level of the INPUT. For semantic relations, semantic relations are the relations

After the format conversion, the remaining text document is a single paragraph with a length of 130 sentences. Figure 3 shows the text format of the first two sentences after conversion. We can see that the first sentence is a sequence of several sentences, while the second sentence is a simple sentence with only one sentence. This is the level of sentence granularity that is used by the system. We also recognize that the text document is a research proposal submitted to the NSF GRF application. For simplicity, we will use the term “research proposal” to denote the text documents. A research proposal is a document that contains a series of text information with the purpose of supporting individuals to be a Winner or Honorable Mention.

2024-05-06 13:43:35 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - The goal is to apply CLUES to determine the overall SUCCESS of the INPUT.

What is CLUES?

CLUES is a method that we have developed to extract content from a research proposal.
The method is comprised of three stages:

Stage 1: Identify key terms, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, and semantic meaning of a research proposal. 
Stage 2: Generate the reason for the success of the proposal based on the extracted key terms, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, and semantic meaning. 
Stage 3: Determine the overall success of the proposal based on the generated reason.

Stage 1

During Stage 1, we identify key terms, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, and semantic meaning of the research proposal.
The first stage is a three-tiered process (as depicted in Figure 1):

Tier 1: Identify key terms and phrases. 
Tier 2: Identify contextual information. 
Tier 3: Identify semantic relations and semantic meaning.

Figure
2024-05-06 13:43:35 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$
2024-05-06 13:43:35 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: retry 18
2024-05-06 13:43:36 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:43:37 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \end{document}

The inputs are scientific research papers extracted from the CV database. The inputs are a list of CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of the scientific research papers.
The CLUES are anti-words, nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, and references.
The inputs are the scientific research papers along with the CLUES.
The outputs of the system are the scientific research papers SUCCESS, which is a SUCCESS classifier to identify whether the scientific research papers are SUCCESS or FAILURE.

The inputs are scientific research papers extracted from the CVDBASE database. The inputs are a list of CLUES (i.e. keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of the scientific research papers.
The CLUES are anti-words, nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, and references

\begin{document}
\section{Introduction}
The following document is a sample submission to \textsc{ICLR} 2021. This document is based on the v2.3.0 of the official \textsc{ICLR} \LaTeX~document class which can be downloaded from https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.13168.

\section{Getting Started}
This document demonstrates the most important features of the \textsc{ICLR} \LaTeX~document class. The document contains 6 sections, although it is very easy to add more. You can add a section by writing \verb|\section{<title>}|. The title will be added to the table of contents (if you compile the document with \verb|xelatex|).

\section{Math}

Unraveling the process of polysaccharide utilization in complex bacterial ecosystems
Intellectual Merit – Introduction: Bacteria do not exist in isolation in nature; they form complex communities in which they must recognize, compete over, and, share nutrient resources.1,2 The gut microbiome is an ideal model to study this type of ecosystem, as we know what nutrients these bacteria are exposed to and have access to powerful tools to study taxonomy and metabolism. Gut bacteria break down polysaccharide nutrients and convert them to health-beneficial end products of metabolism called short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) that are taken up and used for energy by host intestinal cells.1,2 However, there is a gap in our understanding of what factors give rise to the emergent phenomenon of SCFA production. Task: Students will investigate the analysis and characterization of the microbiome. Students will use the human microbiome as a means of exploring the need for computational approaches in microbiome research and data analysis. The human microbiome is an assemblage of microbes that live in or on the human body and are essential for human health and disease. Specifically, the task will ask students to answer the following questions: 1. What is the role of the microbiome in human health and disease? 2. What is the microbiome and how is it studied? 3. What computational tools are necessary for microbiome research? 4. What computational tools are needed for microbiome data analysis? 5. What are the challenges of using computational tools in microbiome research?

INPUT: Motivation: We have developed a novel platform for measuring the structure and dynamics of individual nanoparticles at liquid-liquid interfaces using chemical force microscopy (CFM). CFM is a sensitive nanoscale force measurement technique that is compatible with various surface chemistries and has been used to detect interactions between nanoparticles, polymers, and biomolecules. The adsorption of nanoparticles to surfaces is critical in many technological and biological applications. In this work, we explore the fundamentals of the interaction between nanoparticles and surfaces using CFM. Hypothesis: We hypothesize that the adhesion force between nanoparticles and probes with specific surface chemistries can be used to measure the contact angle between the nanoparticles and a surface. 1. Motivation
Motivation: The small numbers of African American, Native American and Latino students receiving doctoral degrees in biomedical engineering (BME) contrasts with the diversity of the U.S. population and the importance that this group will play in the future of the field. In 2014, the proportion of U.S. citizens and permanent residents in BME who were African American, Native American, and Latino was 5%, 1%, and 6%, respectively, which does not reflect the population of the United States. The limited diversity in the field is of concern because the underrepresentation reduces the ability of the discipline to address the health needs of all populations and contributes to the isolation of underrepresented minority students in graduate school. INPUT: Motivation: Virus purification and concentration is critical for the production of vaccines and gene therapy vectors. Today, vaccines exist for 26 viral diseases, but low yields and high costs of production prevent access to many vaccines. Similarly, production limitations will reduce access to viral gene therapy, which may provide cures to single-mutation genetic diseases. Although many technologies exist for virus particle purification, they each face unique roadblocks to developing rapid, high-yielding, and ultimately continuous processes. Chromatography is widely-used for virus purification, but suffers from low binding capacities, frequently inactivates viruses, and cannot operate continuously. Ultrafiltration is readily scalable and provides high throughput and recoveries, but fouling reduces flux and removal of contaminating proteins is often ineffective. Ultracentrifugation is difficult to scale up and has low yield, even though purities are high. Aqueous two-phase systems (ATPS), most commonly constructed with two polymers or a polymer

Have a look at this answer which deals with the same issue, but for the align environment instead of enumerate. The trick is to define a custom environment which you can then use in your enumerate environment. Show your MWE and explain how your enumerate environment is different from the one in my answer and I can try to help you further. – user31729 Jan 14 at 14:32

A different approach, as depicted in Figure 2, categorized the success of the GRF applicants into two main categories: Winner and Honorable Mention. The purpose of the model is to assess whether the applicant will be awarded the GRF Winner or Honorable Mention. This model was developed from the keywords, phrases, and contextual information of the GRF proposals and the success of the applicants. Figure 2 shows the overall framework of this model. The inputs are the list of CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT, and the INPUT. The CLUES were obtained from the NSF GRF application, which contained a list of keywords, phrases, and contextual information. The CLUES were also obtained from the semantic relations, semantic meaning, and tones of the INPUT and the CLUES. Update: A complete MWE is here

A solution is to use the verbatim environment from the fancyvrb package.

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{fancyvrb}
\begin{document}
\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,label={A real GRF submission}]
INPUT: Motivation: Virus purification and concentration is critical for the production of vaccines and gene therapy vectors. Today, vaccines exist for 26 viral diseases1, but low yields and high costs of production prevent access to many vaccines. Similarly, production limitations will reduce access to viral gene therapy, which may provide cures to single-mutation genetic diseases. Although many technologies exist for virus particle purification, they each face unique roadblocks to developing rapid, high-yielding, and ultimately continuous processes. Chromatography is widely-used for virus purification, but suffers from

2024-05-06 13:45:11 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - RESULTS
Evaluation of the success is a major challenge in the field of natural language processing (NLP).
Machine learning has been widely used in this field. 
There are two types of evaluation. 
The evaluation that is based on supervised machine learning (SML) is called a supervised evaluation.
The evaluation that is based on unsupervised machine learning (UML) is called an unsupervised evaluation.
The evaluation based on both supervised and unsupervised machine learning is called a hybrid evaluation.
The results of the GRF applications are evaluated based on the SML classifier. 
The results of the GRF applications are evaluated based on the UML classifier.
The results of the GRF applications are evaluated based on the hybrid classifier.

SML

Classification Accuracy: 
The classification accuracy is the ratio of the number of correctly classified cases to
the total number of cases.
The classification accuracy is 76\%. 
The classification accuracy is based on the GRF application status.
The classification accuracy

\usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}

In order to study DM astrophysically, we must use the luminous parts of the universe — the galaxies and galaxy clusters that reside inside DM halos — as tracers. Back to the top

This is an example document for CLUES, a content analysis system for full-text documents. CLUES reads a TEX document and generates a CLUES document by recognizing the input keywords (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) of the input document. The CLUES document contains the recognized keywords with the semantic meaning. The recognized keywords are extracted from the input document and are listed as a list of CLUES. The semantic meaning of the keywords is defined. The CLUES document can be used to generate a summary of the input document. The summary is composed of the CLUES. The CLUES document can be used for document clustering purposes.

CLUES uses a custom-made word tokenizer by splitting the input document into words. The tokenization is

INPUT: Intellectual Merit Microscopy has long been a powerful tool for the study of biological systems, a field of study known as microscopy. Microscopes provide a way for scientists to see what is happening inside the cell. The use of microscopy is important in the study of biology, as it helps scientists to better understand the inner workings of living organisms. There are a variety of types of microscopes. The type of microscope used depends on the objective of the experiment. The most common type of microscope is the optical microscope. Optical microscopes use visible light to observe specimens. One of the advantages of optical microscopy is that it does not require special equipment to operate. Unlike other kinds of microscopes, an optical microscope can be used by anyone and doesn’t require any special training. INPUT: Motivation: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) allows non-invasive measurement of real-time brain activity in humans. The success of this technology has been evidenced by its rapid growth in popularity in the 25 years of its existence, resulting in nearly 40,000 research papers^1. A large portion of these studies investigates the correlational structure of the brain signal, known as functional connectivity (FC). FC studies are most often implemented in resting state fMRI (RS-fMRI). Historically RS-fMRI has been especially useful in clinical and developmental imaging because it requires no task demands, avoids performance confounds and measures network connectivity in largely the same way that task fMRI does^2. These methods have led to many groundbreaking findings in brain science that were previously inaccessible. Recent evidence^3 has shown that many of these findings may be spurious

add a comment |  

up vote 5 down vote

There is an easy way to do this using the term-lists package: A list of terms can be defined using

\newtermlist{name}{list of terms}

and then used to automatically generate the list using

\termlist{label}{name}

This package is designed for use in scientific reports, but it works well for this purpose too. Here's a quick example:

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{term-list}

\newtermlist{name}{Motivation, Aims, Broader Impacts}

\begin{document}
\termlist{mylabel}{name}
\end{document}

\title{Congruence of Keywords, Phrases, Contextual Information, Semantic Relations, Semantic Meaning, Tones, and References for Determining the Overall Success of Research Proposals}
\author{Xin Li}
\date{March 2017}
\maketitle

\begin{abstract}
This paper discusses the input of a research proposal and the congruence of keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, and references for determining the overall success of a research proposal submitted to NSF GRF applications. The conclusion is that the correct congruence of keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, and references is able to determine the overall success of a research proposal.
\end{abstract}

Inquire Within is a hands-on, inquiry-based science curriculum that emphasizes the scientific method and encourages critical thinking. It is designed to be used in a variety of settings, but I have modified the curriculum and will test it in my own middle school classroom. My goal is to determine if the Inquire Within curriculum is an effective way to teach science and to identify areas for improvement. Inquire Within provides a framework for the scientific method that can be adjusted to match the level of students’ scientific knowledge and critical thinking abilities. The exercises ask students to develop hypotheses, test those hypotheses using the scientific method, and then use their results to decide whether their original hypothesis was correct or incorrect. \label{sec:clues_inference}

2024-05-06 13:48:36 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$
2024-05-06 13:48:36 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: retry 8
2024-05-06 13:48:37 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:48:38 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \end{document}

The problem is that I'm not able to use the \begin{document} command correctly. I get the error "Missing \endcsname inserted." when I try to compile the .tex file.

Thank you in advance!

You need to remove the blank line after the \begin{document} line:

\begin{document}

should be

\begin{document}

With modern TeX engines, you can also use \begin{document}{...} which will prevent the compilation error, but the blank line will still be inserted.

@egreg Thank you! I just used your first solution and it worked. – Luis Borges Apr 23 '18 at 17:42 

Not the answer you're looking for? Browse other questions tagged errors writing or ask your own question.

\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage{float}

\begin{document}

\section{Abstract}
\label{sec:abstract}
\begin{abstract}

\end{abstract}

\end{document}

\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\end{abstract}

\end{document}

Acknowledgement

CRISPR/Cas9 mediated knockouts and ectopic overexpression

CRISPR/Cas9 and geminiviruses will be used to produce knock-ins of advantageous alleles in the homologous native location in the Kitaake background. Alleles selected will belong to the haplotype associated with the highest significance SNPs from the most drought tolerant accessions. Useful variation may exist in promoters, genes, or non-coding sequences. This variation will be leveraged using the high replication rates of geminivirus replicons to increase rates of homology-directed repair, with precise positioning enabled by CRISPR/Cas9 mediated double-stranded breaks9.

Welcome to TeX.SE! This is a very tricky problem with many ways to approach it. I'm not sure if this is really a duplicate of the question you link to, which is about a simple example. The best way to approach this is to break it down into parts (I suggest starting with a single input line to begin with), and then try to solve them one at a time. – G. Poore May 7 at 14:23

For what it's worth, I think this is a duplicate of the question you link to. – G. Poore May 7 at 14:26

2024-05-06 13:49:59 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:50:00 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \end{document} 

Note that the keywords are obtained by looking at the training data. The process of identifying keywords is an important part of the process. The keywords are determined based on the wording of the problem statement, and the long tail is pretty well covered. The results of this iterative process are then used to train the classifier. The result is a classifier that can make predictions based on the text. In my research, I have found that the classifier is able to accurately identify the overall success of an NSF GRFP application.

The output of the classifier is a set of textual keywords. These keywords are then used as a starting point for a diagnostic reasoning process. In this process, the keywords are mapped to concepts in the knowledge base that are related to the success of the application. The concepts are then mapped to diagnostic reasoning rules. The reasoning rules are used to determine the overall success of the application. In this manner, the classifier and the diagnostic reasoning process are used together to determine the overall
2024-05-06 13:50:00 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$
2024-05-06 13:50:00 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: retry 2
2024-05-06 13:50:01 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:50:02 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \end{document}

Add comment

Peer review

Reviewer's report

This paper presents original work in the area of Lie algebraic data mining. In particular, the author uses the context of the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program to define a problem and then to present an approach to solve it. The proposed approach is well motivated and the author answers the questions of the reviewers in a satisfactory manner. 
The writing is clear and the paper is well organized. The author has listed the references in alphabetical order which is good and better than the traditional way of listing them in order of appearance in the paper. 
In one of the reviewer's comments, the author has been asked to comment on the quality of the datasets. The author has replied that these datasets are used here for the first time and that there is no formal way of assessing the quality of the

B.2.2.3 
Neural architecture search for the detection of human faces 
Yun Ji , Jihyun Lee , Hyunwoo Choi , Sang-Won Lee , and Insung Ihm 

Abstract

The human face is a unique and dynamic object and it is important to detect faces everywhere. In this work, we propose a neural architecture search method for the face detection. The proposed method consists of two steps. First, we train the CNN for the face detection and extract feature maps from the trained CNN. Second, we use the extracted feature maps to search for the efficient neural network architecture for the face detection. The proposed method shows the improvement in the performance in the face detection.

Input: Feature maps of the CNN and labels of the face
Method: Neural Architecture Search (NAS) for the Efficient Neural Network Architecture for the Face Detection
Result: Efficient Neural Network Architecture for the Face Detection

INPUT: Feature maps of the CNN

Introduction

CS: In this work, we focus on a particular dataset from the field of knowledge graph (KG) completion. The dataset consists of 1 024 755 triples consisting of items of various types (e.g., movie, actor, director, etc.) along with beliefs about the relations between items (e.g., whether a given actor is in a given movie). The task is to predict the missing relation of an item given the context of item’s relation type and its neighbors in the KG. Previous methods for this task can be divided into two main categories: rule-based (e.g., deductive rules) and learnable methods. The latter one can be further divided into matrix factorization-based methods (e.g., matrix factorization) and deep-learning-based methods (e.g., graph neural networks). The main goal of the project is to create a tool that allows to analyze the information contained in a document and to transform it into diagrams of activities and/or events that describe the activities or events mentioned in the document. The transformation of the information contained in a document into diagrams or graphs is called ontology or semantic classification of the document.

The main objective of the project is to conduct an analysis of the activities and/or events contained in the documents considered, and to transform that information into diagrams of activities and/or events that describe those activities or events. To this end, I propose the use of an ontology that supports the semantic classification of documents and that allows the creation of diagrams for each document in the corpus. This ontology will be based on the work of Open Lexicon and the UMLS ontology. This ontology will be modified to support the creation of diagrams of activities and/or events.

We have presented the overall success of the application for NSF GRF by building the diagnostic reasoning model. We also discussed the prerequisite knowledge to identify the success of the application and the difference between success and failure in the application. Introduction to the Meme Talk

The meme talk is a new talk format proposed by Dr. Zhusong Jian for the first time in the 2021 FUSE Online Conference. The meme talk is a 5-minute talk that introduces a topic, a news, a research, a process, an idea, etc. in fun and creative ways. The meme talk can be delivered in different forms including Memes, TikTok, Internet, Youtube, etc.

We use NLP to build a machine learning model to predict the overall success of GRF applications. 
\end{block}

We input research proposals, and outputs are the Winner or Honorable Mention.
\end{block}

Our model will take in a research proposal and generate an overall success score for that proposal.

We want to predict this output value for each application.

2024-05-06 13:54:07 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - Citation: NSF GRFP Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (NSF 2054322)
2021 Winter Simulation Conference Proceedings, pp. 1-12.
Abstract: We propose a method for improving the efficiency of the simulation-based search algorithm, which is the state-of-the-art method for solving the combinatorial optimization problems. Our method combines the advantages of the sampling-based and the optimization-based methods. The core of our method is to use the fast simulation-based search algorithm to explore the search space and determine the candidate solutions, and then use the optimization-based method to efficiently search for the global optimum of the candidate solutions. This method is easy to implement and can significantly speed up the search process. We have tested our method on the test problems and compared it with the baseline algorithm. The experimental results show that our method is significantly more efficient in terms of the computational time, and the quality of the results is comparable to the baseline algorithm.
Citation: Artificial Intelligence 295, pp.

2024-05-06 13:55:23 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - prompt_and_result
2024-05-06 13:55:24 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - CLUES: This is a success classifier to identify the overall SUCCESS (WINNER or HM) of INPUT. First, list CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information, semantic relations, semantic meaning, tones, references) for determining the overall SUCCESS of INPUT by the use of the term “success classifier”.
Second, induce a diagnostic REASONING process from CLUES and the INPUT for determining the overall SUCCESS (Limit the number of words to 130).
Third, determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT as Winner or Honorable Mention considering CLUES, the REASONING process and the INPUT.

\section{The proposed system}
\label{sec:system}

The model proposed in this paper can be divided into two main parts: the first part is the input and the second part is the proposed reasoning system. The input is the candidate text of the research article. The proposed system takes the candidate text as input and outputs the text with semantic relations and tones of the text. Figure~\ref{fig:system} shows the system diagram of the proposed system. The proposed system starts with a preprocessing process to clean the text and then the input is sent to the tonality extractor and semantic relation extractor. The tonality extractor extracts the tonality of the input text and the semantic relation extractor extracts the semantic relation of the input text. These extracted tonality and semantic relation are then sent to the semantic analyzer to generate the semantic relation and tonality of the input text. The semantic analyzer uses the extracted tonality and semantic relation to generate the
2024-05-06 13:56:35 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$

2024-05-06 13:56:38 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - \newpage

INPUT: Title: The effects of environmental enrichment on the gut microbiome of captive zoo mammals Background: The gut microbiota is a community of microorganisms that lives in the gastroin- testinal tract. Within this community, there are beneficial bacteria that aid in digestion and immune function. The gut microbiota has been shown to be significantly influenced by the environment. In particular, there are studies that show the gut microbiota is influenced by the social environment (i.e. the company the animal is living in) and the physical environment (i.e. the enclosure). Our project focuses on the effects of environmental enrichment on the gut microbiota of zoo mammals. Environmental enrichment (EE) is a concept whereby animals are given the opportunity to engage in natural behaviors and in activities that promote mental and physical well being. Enrichment is also beneficial to the mental health of the animals, and is often used as a behavior modification technique in zoo animals. Previous studies have shown that social enrichment can

It is important to note that the text for the inputs are not written by the researchers. This is done by a data scientist after conducting research on all the papers to determine the most frequent terms that appear in the inputs and the outputs for the dataset.

What we want to do is to use this dataset to train a deep learning model that has the ability to predict the overall success of the application of an NSF GRF. The details of how we used deep learning and our approach is described in the next section.

2.2 Approach

In this study, the overall success of the NSF GRF application is determined by inspecting the inputs and outputs from the dataset. We used a deep learning approach to learn the overall success for these inputs. The inputs are research proposals submitted to NSF GRF applications and this is a overall success classifier to identify whether the applicants will be the Winner or Honorable Mention. First, inspect CLUES (i.e., keywords, phrases, contextual information

When you say "the device produces pro-inflammatory neutrophils", do you mean that the neutrophils in the model are somehow different from those in the real world? – tim Jul 16 '17 at 18:19
1
@tim I think the question is that we already know that neutrophils in the device are pro-inflammatory, but the authors want to know why. – Ruslan Jul 16 '17 at 18:37
I think the "the objective of my research" is to create a model that produces pro-inflammatory neutrophils. The text and figures are giving an overview of how the model is built. – user2289 Jul 16 '17 at 19:03

-CREATE_DATE: The date that the research proposal was created.
-RESUBMITTED: Whether the research proposal is a resubmission or not.
-URBAN: The city of the research proposal.
-UNIVERSITY: The university, college, or institution of the research proposal.
-COLLEGE: The college, school, or department of the research proposal.
-RESEARCH: The research area of the research proposal.
-INTEREST: Whether the research proposal is about the research interest of the author.
-CONNECTION: Whether the research proposal is connected to other research proposal.
-ASSISTANT: Whether the research proposal is assisted by others.
-MENTOR: Whether the research proposal is mentored by others.

Perceptions of the Future of Health Care

by Mallory Kelly, University of Notre Dame

ABSTRACT

Health care has been a major topic of conversation in the United States for some time now. With the future of Obamacare still in question, many people are wondering what the future of health care looks like. This study examines the perceptions of health care held by undergraduate students, and how those perceptions may change with education. A survey was given to undergraduate students at the University of Notre Dame. The survey included one open-ended question and several Likert-scale questions. The question asked was “What is your definition of health care?” and several questions explored students’ definitions and perceptions of the following topics: health care as a basic human need, health care as a privilege, and health care as a business. The results of this study show that undergraduate students at the University of Notre

A Comprehensive Approach to Improving Prediction of Climate Change Impacts on the Hydrologic Cycle

Hydrological systems are affected by climate change in many different ways. For example, future climatic conditions are projected to change the frequency of extreme weather events, such as floods and droughts. It is well known that climate change has a significant impact on the global hydrologic cycle. However, past studies have often focused on specific aspects of the hydrologic cycle, such as precipitation or evapotranspiration. With the goal of improving prediction of climate change impacts on the hydrologic cycle, this work proposes a comprehensive approach to understanding the effects of climate change on the hydrologic cycle. The proposed approach is based on the framework of the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) Continental-scale International Project (GCIP). The key idea of this framework is the separation of precipitation and evaporation into two independent processes, and this

\begin{abstract}
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship (GRF) Program, which is the oldest and most prestigious graduate fellowship of its kind, is a highly competitive and prestigious fellowship awarded to graduate students for pursuing doctoral studies in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. The NSF GRF application and the success outcome of the application have the significant impact on future career of graduate students. Authors: Brianna Marie Torres, Kevin D. O'Gorman, and Michael O. Oborne
Affiliation: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of South Florida
Poster ID: 1080
Abstract:
In this research, we investigate the use of natural language processing for the classification of implicit gender stereotypes in NSF applications. This research is motivated by a rising concern for gender bias in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Stereotypes are tightly linked with biases and the assessment of gender stereotypes can provide a tool for identifying implicit gender bias. We focus on the detection of gender stereotypes due to the larger volume of research related to gender bias in the context of gender stereotypes. However, the methods described in this research can be used in other contexts, such as other types of bias (e.g., racial bias). We present three classification

2024-05-06 13:58:28 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - GOLDEN KEY: A Conceptual Framework for the Success of Education for Sustainability (EfS) in School Curricula in the United States
Karin D. Krynicki, The College of New Jersey, Environmental Science, 2000 Pennington-Rocky Hill Rd., Ewing, NJ 08628, kdkrnicki@gmail.com
Keywords: education for sustainability; sustainability education; curriculum integration; conceptual framework; change approach; teacher acceptance
Abstract: Education for sustainability (EfS) is a framework for preparing future citizens to be able to make decisions and take actions that are sustainable — economically, socially, and ecologically. EfS is a key component of the 21st-century skills movement, and also of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In the United States, EfS has been a priority of many organizations, but is not part of national or state standards or curricula. \section{Introduction}
\label{sec:intro}
Rising temperatures in the subarctic are accelerating thaw of organic-rich permafrost peatlands, liberating organic carbon (C) from long term storage through microbial decomposition, and increasing methane (CH) emissions \cite{1,2}. 
Methanotrophic bacteria can oxidize 4 (consume) CH in thawing peatlands, producing carbon dioxide (CO) \cite{3,4}. 
Recent biogeochemical research has elucidated the controls of CH production and flux in thawing peatlands; however, 4 CH oxidation and its controls remain significantly less understood than CH flux. 4 2 Both CH flux and CH oxidation vary along the gradient of permafrost thaw. As thaw 4 4 occurs

Anoikis, the process by which cells detach from their extracellular matrix and undergo apoptosis, is important for tissue development and homeostasis. Anoikis pathways are disrupted in many cancers, and overexpression of ETS-binding TFs is associated with metastasis, tumor recurrence, and poor prognosis. BACKGROUND: Coral reefs provide services totaling $10 trillion despite covering only ~0.3% of the ocean floor1. Their evolutionary success relies on the association between coral animals and symbiotic algae. Corals provide shelter and nutrients for symbionts which in turn supply sugars and O to their hosts2. Corals host symbionts within the symbiosome, an intracellular space 2 defined by the coral-derived symbiosome membrane. This membrane is thought to allow corals to regulate delivery of nutrients to the symbiont but the specific transport mechanisms are mostly unknown. Alarmingly, human-caused ocean warming, acidification, and eutrophication disrupt this symbiosis leading to the expulsion of symbionts (known as ‘bleaching’), decreased coral fitness, and death2. However, the lack of mechanistic knowledge of healthy symbiosis impairs our ability to understand why bleaching occurs, identify resilient and vulnerable species, and design conservation strategies. The mechanisms that

What does the documentclass "article" do?

article is the standard LaTeX document class for articles. It provides a title page, sections, subsections, lists, tables, figures, footnotes, labels, cross-references and more. The documentclass article is based on the book class, which was designed for books. It provides a better layout for books than article. However, for papers article is the better choice. It is much easier to prepare a paper in article than in book. book is a good choice for books, and for books and papers in general. It provides a better layout than article, but is more complex than article.

What is the difference between \input and \include?

\input and \include are used to get text from a file into a LaTeX document. \input is the preferred command for general use and is generally more robust. \include has some other features, such as the ability to turn off chapter numbering and to start at a

1. Introduction
Coral reefs are considered among the most productive ecosystems in the world, estimated to provide services totaling $10 trillion despite covering only ~0.3% of the ocean floor1. Their evolutionary success relies on the association between coral animals and symbiotic algae. Corals provide shelter and nutrients for symbionts which in turn supply sugars and O to their hosts2. Corals host symbionts within the symbiosome, an intracellular space3 defined by the coral-derived symbiosome membrane. This membrane is thought to allow corals to regulate delivery of nutrients to the symbiont but the specific transport mechanisms are mostly unknown. Alarmingly, human-caused ocean warming, acidification, and eutrophication disrupt this symbiosis leading to the expulsion of symbionts (known as ‘bleaching’

Westra, and Lucian Ciortuz.} The Curent OpenReview system (Curent) is a peer-review platform for open science. The system is meant to improve the peer-review process in various ways, for instance, by providing the reviewers with access to the raw data, by removing the need for non-disclosure agreements (NDAs), and by providing the authors with access to the raw reviews that are received for their submissions. Curent is currently used by a small number of journals, but it is not clear whether it is suitable for widespread adoption. Convergent evolution of traits has been widely observed throughout the animal kingdom; however, it is often unclear whether this phenotypic convergence results from convergent evolution of genes (Stern, Nat Rev Genet 2013). On a molecular level, convergent evolution occurs when the amino acids of a specific protein preferentially undergo mutations that produce similar or even identical amino acid sequences within distinct evolutionary lineages. A high level of adaptive convergent evolution – that is, convergence due to positive selection of beneficial mutations – would suggest that some genes have “optimal configurations,” which evolution uses and reuses across species. If such genes exist, then evolution is somewhat predictable, proceeding by one of a small number of possible paths (Stern & Orgogozo, Science 2008). In contrast, a complete absence of adaptive convergence would indicate that protein configurations beneficial to one species are seldom optimal within

2024-05-06 14:00:41 - GPT3-Text-Classification : - INFO: returned results - INPUT: Fluid dynamics of the interstellar medium at large and small scales Key words: Interstellar Medium, Interstellar Turbulence, Magnetohydrodynamics Background and Significance The interstellar medium (ISM) is the vast reservoir of gas and dust that pervades the galaxy, and it is the environment in which stars form. Over 99% of the ISM is in the gaseous phase, and is composed of mainly hydrogen and helium with trace amounts of heavier elements. The ISM is a diffuse, dynamic, and turbulent medium. Turbulence is a state of disorder and rapid fluctuations in velocity, density, pressure, and temperature. The ISM is a turbulent medium, where in large scales the turbulent motions are related to large-scale motions in the galactic disk, such as spiral waves, galactic rotation, and supernova explosions. 3. A2: RIMs for Predicting the Funding Success in Science

MRC, UIC

Rationale

This problem is to determine the overall SUCCESS of INPUT. INPUT is a research proposal submitted to NSF GRF applications. INPUT is a set of 130 words (a list of keywords). The SUCCESS of INPUT is the Winner or Honorable Mention. The Winner is awarded the NSF GRF. The Honorable Mention is considered a highly competitive applicant. The overall SUCCESS is determined by CLUES, REASONING process and the INPUT. RIM is a combination of the CLUES and the REASONING process. RIM is the overall SUCCESS of INPUT. RIM is a 130 word (a list of keywords) with a confidence score from 0 (not at all confident) to

@p4r4d0x I think you are understating the problem. While there are a variety of ways to solve this problem, the approach I took was to simplify the problem by focusing on the distinction between Winner and Honorable Mention. I think this is the first step in any problem, determine the classes you wish to predict.

The human factor analysis of human-robot teams in the industrial setting
This research assesses the human factor analysis of human-robot teams in the industrial setting. The research objectives are to: (1) examine the human-robot interaction in the assembly line, (2) identify the current state of human-robot interaction in the industrial setting, and (3) identify improvement opportunities in human-robot interaction in the industrial setting. The research method includes the literature review and the semi-structured interviews. The literature review includes human factors and ergonomics, inter-human interaction, human-robot interaction, and the industrial setting. The Internet of Things (IoT) is an ecosystem of physical objects that are embedded with sensors, electronics, software, and connectivity in order to collect and exchange data. In the tourism industry, the IoT allows businesses to collect data about visitors, and then use the data to provide services that meet and even exceed customer expectations. There are many opportunities for research on the IoT and tourism, since the IoT has already made an impact on many areas of tourism such as hospitality, attractions, transportation, and event management. However, most of the work on the IoT and tourism is descriptive and does not provide a strong theoretical foundation. Computer Science, Computer Science Education

D. E. Kerns

Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences

Berkeley, CA

D. E. Kerns is a Ph.D. student at UC Berkeley, in the School of Information, with research interests in data science and social science. She currently works with the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences (BITSS) and the Open Science Collaboration to help increase research transparency and reproducibility in the social sciences.

Crucial to the success of any scientific enterprise is the ability to replicate and extend past research. Yet replication rates for social science studies are alarmingly low: only 36% of studies in psychology and 11% in economics are successfully replicated[1]. A lack of reproducibility can be due to any number of factors, but in the case of social science it is often the result of a lack of standardization, or of the failure to adhere to previously published guidance.
